str2: A primary particle; but, and, etc.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 1st Person Singular
str2: To hope, hope for, expect, trust. From elpis; to expect or confide.
Properly, to stare at, i.e. to discern clearly; by extension, to attend to; by Hebraism, to experience; passively, to appear.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Accusative 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
Immediately, soon, at once. Adverb from euthus; directly, i.e. At once or soon.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Future Indicative Active - 1st Person Plural
str2: A prolonged form of an otherwise obsolete verb; to talk, i.e. Utter words.
The mouth, speech, eloquence in speech, the point of a sword.
To, towards, with. A strengthened form of pro; a preposition of direction; forward to, i.e. Toward.
The mouth, speech, eloquence in speech, the point of a sword.
Probably from a primary verb eiro; peace; by implication, prosperity.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Friendly; subst: a friend, an associate. Properly, dear, i.e. A friend; actively, fond, i.e. Friendly.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle or Passive - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To greet, salute, pay my respects to, welcome. To enfold in the arms, i.e. to salute, to welcome.

parse: Verb - Present Imperative Middle or Passive - 2nd Person Singular
str2: To greet, salute, pay my respects to, welcome. To enfold in the arms, i.e. to salute, to welcome.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Friendly; subst: a friend, an associate. Properly, dear, i.e. A friend; actively, fond, i.e. Friendly.
A primary particle; down, in varied relations (genitive, dative or accusative) with which it is joined).
Name, character, fame, reputation. From a presumed derivative of the base of ginosko; a 'name'.
